plain_text.words: One of the basic concepts in Isabelle is rule application.
A rule consists of a list of premises and a conclusion.
The conclusion is that the union
The variables starting with a question mark denote schematic variables, which we can replace with arbitrary terms of the correct type.
and get a specialized version of the rule:
When applying a rule, the conclusion is matched against the current goal.
If it matches, the goal is replaced by the premises of the rule.
As an example consider the following Lemma:
After starting the proof with this rule, we are left with the following 2 subgoals:

antiquoted.language: @{term[show_abbrevs=false] \<open>'a \<Rightarrow> 'a set \<Rightarrow> 'a setinsert 'aa ('a \<Rightarrow> 'a set \<Rightarrow> 'a setinsert 'ab ('a \<Rightarrow> 'a set \<Rightarrow> 'a setinsert 'ac {}))\<close>}

plain_text.words: The proof above is probably the most verbose and explicit way it can be formulated in Isabelle.
First of all, Isabelle can often figure out the values for schematic variables in rules by matching the conclusion and the goal.
So we can simply omit the
When functions are involved, matching can become a bit more complicated.
When a proof can be completed with a single step, it can be abbreviated using
For exploration and for short proofs it can be tedious to write down all subgoals explicitly using
We can avoid this by starting the proof with
This will just transform the current proof state and we can directly continue on this state with other calls to
We have no more subgoals and can complete the proof with
Note that this style of proof can be hard to follow by just reading the proof text since the proof text contains no information about the intermediate steps.
The proof above contains several repeated lines.
We can add a plus to a proof method to repeat it as often as it is applicable:
method accepts several rules (which will be tried from left to right), we can the combine the proof to a single line:
